title: PGIM eyes high performing currencies in low yield world
text:
"We do think that low global growth will continue for a couple more quarters."

China is also part of the global slowdown story, with growth in the world's second largest economy decelerating to a 30-year low of 6 per cent in the third quarter.

Mr Banasiak backs President Xi Jinping's decision to move away from the debt fuelled stop-go approach to growth that has been a characteristic of China's economy.

"There is a huge overhang of debt – at 270 per cent of GDP – so he's doing the right thing by not re-leveraging the economy because the NPLs [non-performing loans] from such a strategy would potentially be high enough to break the banking system."

Despite the slower growth PGIM is upbeat on the outlook for Chinese bonds given the fatter yields on offer along the yield curve, which Mr Banasiak said is one of the steeper curves in the world.

China's two-year bond yields 2.67 per cent (compared to 1.58 per cent in the US) and the 30-year bond yields 3.76 per cent (compared to 2.24 per cent).

"From a real yield standpoint Chinese bonds are attractive."

Another attraction of Chinese bonds is the expectation of increased capital flows following their inclusion into the closely-watched Bloomberg Barclays Global Aggregate Index in April. Chinese bonds are likely to be included in other major benchmarks.

"There's bound to be more inflows into China and it's an attractive bond market. Historically it's been a relatively stable currency, it still sports a current account surplus."

Indonesia is another country catching the money manager's eye. The push by President Joko Widodo to reform the economy of Australia's northern neighbour is seen as a positive, so too the prospect for further interest rate cuts.

"They have a structural reform effort, they have relatively high growth, they're relatively insulated from global trade, and they have relatively high real rates, so for us that's one of the more attractive bond markets to be in," Mr Banasiak said.

PGIM likes Indonesian government bonds with five- to seven-year maturities.

Among emerging market currencies, it's the Russian rouble that has been a "standout outperfomer". It's up about 8 per cent against the US dollar despite the weakness in oil prices.

"The current account of Russia is at 7 per cent of GDP – it is as high as it was back in 2007 when oil prices went north of $US100.

"The current account surplus is the dominant factor in keeping the currency stable, so it's no longer the fluctuation in the price of oil."

And the hryvnia? Well, it's rallied around 11 per cent against the US dollar from its January lows.

There's a new populist president but the country is keen to extend its IMF program, which could lead to improvements in Ukraine's economy.

"A lot of the conditions that are demanded by the IMF, that includes an increase in productivity, labour reforms, and opening the market to have more access to private property, will go a long way to increasing productivity and increasing the potential GDP of the country," said Mr Banasiak.
description: PGIM Fixed Income's Mariusz Banasiak says Chinese bonds are "attractive", is upbeat on Indonesia, and sees opportunity in Russia and Ukraine.
